In the first dilution (1:10^7), the density is high enough that most cells will have either no mutations or one mutation. But since some cells have both, the actual count might be higher than expected if we just looked at either mutation alone. However, because the two mutations are independent, the probability of both appearing in the same cell is the product of their individual probabilities. Similarly, on the second plate, 40 pluses were found on K, indicating 40 cells had the phage carrying mutation in the lysogenic form. Wait, no—actually, the phage carrying mutation could be either lysogenic or phage-specific, depending on what caused the problem.

In this case, the lysogenic phage (mutated) leads to cell lysis, whereas the phage-specific mutation may not affect lysosins, so the lysogenic effect wouldn't occur. Therefore, the lysogenic phage carries the mutation that leads to lytic fission, and the phage-specific carries the mutation that leads to lysogenic fission.

When both are present, recombination occurs, leading to double-stranded phage DNA. This can interfere with replication and affect growth.
